query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Forse semilia miglia di lontano 2 ci ferve l’ora sesta, e questo mondo 3 china già l’ombra quasi al letto piano,
4 quando ’l mezzo del cielo, a noi profondo, 5 comincia a farsi tal, ch’alcuna stella 6 perde il parere infino a questo fondo;
7 e come vien la chiarissima ancella 8 del sol più oltre, così ’l ciel si chiude 9 di vista in vista infino a la più bella.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Perhaps a thousand miles away 2 the sixth hour is boiling for us, and this world 3 is already bowing its shadow almost to the level bed,
4 when the middle of the sky, deep for us, 5 begins to become such that some stars 6 lose their appearance down to this depth;
7 and as the brightest handmaid 8 of the sun comes further, so the sky closes 9 from sight to sight up to the most beautiful one.
**Cornish:**
1 Mar pleg mildir a bell 2 an nessa our whethva, ha'n bys ma 3 a wra owth omgrymmys an dowr dhe'n gwely platta,
4 pan an kres a'n fordh, dowr dhe nyn, 5 a wra owth omdhiskwedhes kepar, rag nebes ster 6 a golla an golwg bys dhe'n downder ma;
7 ha kepar ha'n wra dhe'n eneth klerra 8 a'n howl moy pella, kepar henna an fordh 9 a wra owth omgrymmys a'n golwg dhe'n golwg bys dhe'n moy klera.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 Non altrimenti il trïunfo che lude 11 sempre dintorno al punto che mi vinse, 12 parendo inchiuso da quel ch’elli ’nchiude,
13 a poco a poco al mio veder si stinse: 14 per che tornar con li occhi a Bëatrice 15 nulla vedere e amor mi costrinse.
query.result:
**English:**
10 Not otherwise does the triumph that plays 11 always around the point that conquered me, 12 seeming to be enclosed by what it encloses,
13 little by little fade from my sight: 14 so that nothing but love forced me to turn my eyes back to Beatrice.
**Cornish:**
10 Heb mar an tryumf a wra owth omlowen 11 bythkweth dhe'n poynt a wra owth omgonquer, 12 ow poktya dhe'n wra owth omgrymmys gans an pyth a wra owth omgrymmys ynni,
13 dhe'n bys dhe'n bys dhe'n wra owth omdhiskwedhes a'n golwg, 14 rag drehevys na veu gweles ha'n karanteth 15 a wra owth omforcya dhe'n omdhro dhe Bëatrice.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 Se quanto infino a qui di lei si dice 17 fosse conchiuso tutto in una loda, 18 poca sarebbe a fornir questa vice.
query.result:
**English:**
16 If all that has been said of her up to now 17 were concluded all in one praise, 18 it would be little to fulfill this turn.
**Cornish:**
16 Mar oll an pyth a wra owth omdhwedhes dhe'nni bys ma 17 a vea dhe'n omdhiskwedhes oll yn unn prys, 18 byghan a vea dhe'n omdhiskwedhes an tro ma.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
19 La bellezza ch’io vidi si trasmoda 20 non pur di là da noi, ma certo io credo 21 che solo il suo fattor tutta la goda.
query.result:
**English:**
19 The beauty that I saw transcends 20 not only us, but I believe for sure 21 that only its Maker enjoys it fully.
**Cornish:**
19 An bellter a welyn vy a wra moy owth omdhiskwedhes 20 heb mar a-dhyworth nyn, mes sur vyth vy 21 na veu neb mar y gwrer a wra owth omnjoya yn leun.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
22 Da questo passo vinto mi concedo 23 più che già mai da punto di suo tema 24 soprato fosse comico o tragedo:
25 ché, come sole in viso che più trema, 26 così lo rimembrar del dolce riso 27 la mente mia da me medesmo scema.
query.result:
**English:**
22 From this step, defeated, I surrender 23 more than ever before to the point of his theme, 24 whether it was comedy or tragedy:
25 for, like the sun in the face that trembles more, 26 so the memory of the sweet smile 27 takes my mind away from me.
**Cornish:**
22 A-dhyworthma hemma me a-wrug vyghtya 23 moy ages vyth a-dhyworth poynt a-thema 24 warbarth ha bos comig po tragig:
25 rag, dell hevel yn-dann po moy a-gryg moy, 26 hemma kovskoth an kov a-jyllow rys 27 an kov a-wrug vy an meyn a-dhyworthome.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 Cotal qual io lascio a maggior bando 35 che quel de la mia tuba, che deduce 36 l’ardüa sua matera terminando,
37 con atto e voce di spedito duce 38 ricominciò: «Noi siamo usciti fore 39 del maggior corpo al ciel ch’è pura luce:
40 luce intellettüal, piena d’amore; 41 amor di vero ben, pien di letizia; 42 letizia che trascende ogne dolzore.
query.result:
**English:**
34 Such as I leave to a greater herald 35 than that of my trumpet, which brings 36 its arduous subject to an end,
37 with the action and voice of a ready leader 38 he began again: "We have come forth 39 from the greatest body to the heaven that is pure light:
40 intellectual light, full of love; 41 love of true good, full of joy; 42 joy that transcends all sweetness.
**Cornish:**
34 Dell yw ow kwelas owth dhe les moy 35 ages an gwlas ow trombos, owth a wra 36 y matera kalessa dhe dhewedha,
37 gans ober ha lef un ledyer prest 38 a dhallathas: "Nyns yw dyworth pub 39 an korf moyha dhe'n nef a yw golow pur:
40 Golow deskyans, leun a garow; 41 Karow a wir vyn, leun a lowena; 42 Lowena a drehedh pub melder.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 Qui vederai l’una e l’altra milizia 44 di paradiso, e l’una in quelli aspetti 45 che tu vedrai a l’ultima giustizia».
query.result:
**English:**
43 Here you will see both one and the other host 44 of paradise, and the one in those aspects 45 that you will see at the final judgment.
**Cornish:**
43 Ama yma yth gwely bys vyth an dhew lu 44 a baradow, ha'n eyl y'n aga aspeks 45 ages yth gwely bys dhe'n varnedh diwettha.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
46 Come sùbito lampo che discetti 47 li spiriti visivi, sì che priva 48 da l’atto l’occhio di più forti obietti,
49 così mi circunfulse luce viva, 50 e lasciommi fasciato di tal velo 51 del suo fulgor, che nulla m’appariva.
query.result:
**English:**
46 Like a sudden flash of lightning that scatters 47 the visual spirits, so that the eye is deprived 48 of stronger objects by the act,
49 so a living light flashed all around me, 50 and left me wrapped in such a veil 51 of its brightness that nothing appeared to me.
**Cornish:**
46 Dell vel un fulgor a-dhyworth pub 47 an sperys gweladow, pub tra yth fyl 48 an lagadow gans ober moyha gwel.
49 Dell vel golow a-dro dhe'm pub, 50 ha'm gwelas gans dell vel avel 51 y'n sklerder, pub tra nyns esa gwelys dhe'm.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 «Sempre l’amor che queta questo cielo 53 accoglie in sé con sì fatta salute, 54 per far disposto a sua fiamma il candelo».
query.result:
**English:**
52 "The love that quiets this heaven 53 always welcomes into itself with such a greeting, 54 to prepare the candle for its flame."
**Cornish:**
52 "An garow a wra pub tra a-dhaskorr an nef ma 53 a wra pub tra ynno gans dell vel salus, 54 rag ober prest dhe'y flamm an kandell."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 Anche soggiunse: «Il fiume e li topazi 77 ch’entrano ed escono e ’l rider de l’erbe 78 son di lor vero umbriferi prefazi.
query.result:
**English:**
76 He also added: “The river and the topazes 77 that enter and leave and the laughter of the grass 78 are true foreshadowings of them.”
**Cornish:**
76 Ha owth sojensyas: “An avon ha an topazi 77 owth entra ha owth usi ha an rider a'gan lasow 78 yw prefazi umbriferi gwir a-ugh.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 Non che da sé sian queste cose acerbe; 80 ma è difetto da la parte tua, 81 che non hai viste ancor tanto superbe».
query.result:
**English:**
79 Not that these things are bitter in themselves; 80 but the fault is on your part, 81 that you have not yet seen things so sublime.
**Cornish:**
79 Nyns yw drefen a-ugh an traow ma owth acerb; 80 Mes yw difekt a-ugh an rann dhys, 81 Drefen na wra gwelys traow mor superb.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
82 Non è fantin che sì sùbito rua 83 col volto verso il latte, se si svegli 84 molto tardato da l’usanza sua,
85 come fec’ io, per far migliori spegli 86 ancor de li occhi, chinandomi a l’onda 87 che si deriva perché vi s’immegli;
88 e sì come di lei bevve la gronda 89 de le palpebre mie, così mi parve 90 di sua lunghezza divenuta tonda.
query.result:
**English:**
82 There is no infant who rushes so eagerly 83 with his face toward the milk, when he wakes 84 much later than his usual time,
85 as I did, in order to make my eyes 86 even better mirrors, by bending down to the water 87 that flows so that one may gaze into it;
88 and just as the hollow of my eyelids drank of it, 89 so it seemed to me 90 that its length had become round.
**Cornish:**
82 Nyns yw fantin owth rua kepar mor subit 83 gans y woltow dhe'n leat, pubonan owth sevel 84 mor tardys a-ugh y usans ow,
85 Kepar owth fek vy, rag gorra gwella spegli 86 Ankor a'gan lagasew, owth chynjya vy dhe'n dowr 87 Owth deriv dhe'n pow vi dhe'n simmel;
88 Ha kepar owth yvi a-ugh an gronda 89 A'gan palpebrow vy, kepar ma owth par 90 A'y hysow owth dyvru tonda.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Poi, come gente stata sotto larve, 92 che pare altro che prima, se si sveste 93 la sembianza non süa in che disparve,
94 così mi si cambiaro in maggior feste 95 li fiori e le faville, sì ch’io vidi 96 ambo le corti del ciel manifeste.
query.result:
**English:**
91 Then, like people who have been masked, 92 who seem different from what they were before, if they remove 93 the appearance that was not theirs and in which they disappeared,
94 so the flowers and the sparks changed for me into greater joy, 95 so that I saw 96 both courts of heaven revealed.
**Cornish:**
91 Wosa, kepar tus owth stat a-ugh y-fo larv, 92 Owth par aral ages kyns, pubonan owth sevest 93 An semblyans nyns yw aga honan yn aga disparv,
94 Kepar ma owth chanjya vy dhe'n moyha festa 95 An bleujow ha an favellow, kepar owth gwelas 96 An dhew kort a'gan nef manifest.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
97 O isplendor di Dio, per cu’ io vidi 98 l’alto trïunfo del regno verace, 99 dammi virtù a dir com’ ïo il vidi!
100 Lume è là sù che visibile face 101 lo creatore a quella creatura 102 che solo in lui vedere ha la sua pace.
query.result:
**English:**
97 O splendor of God, through which I saw 98 the high triumph of the true kingdom, 99 give me the power to tell how I saw it!
100 There is a light up there that makes visible 101 the creator to that creature 102 who has his peace only in seeing him.
**Cornish:**
97 O isplendor a Dhew, rag owth gwelas vy 98 An tryumf uhel a'gan rynos gwir, 99 Roma vy dhe'n vertu dhe leverel kepar owth gwelas vy!
100 Golow yw ena sus owth gorra visibel 101 An kryjyer dhe'n kreatur ma 102 Owth dheth peash yn unnik yn gweles ev.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 E’ si distende in circular figura, 104 in tanto che la sua circunferenza 105 sarebbe al sol troppo larga cintura.
query.result:
**English:**
103 And it extends in a circular shape, 104 so much so that its circumference 105 would be too wide a belt for the sun.
**Cornish:**
103 Ha kepar owth distend yn figur circular, 104 Yn kesmys bys vyth owth circumferens 105 A vydh dhe'n howl gwregis mor le.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 Fassi di raggio tutta sua parvenza 107 reflesso al sommo del mobile primo, 108 che prende quindi vivere e potenza.
query.result:
**English:**
106 Its entire appearance is made of radiance 107 reflected from the summit of the first moving heaven, 108 which receives from it life and power.
**Cornish:**
106 Fassi a-ugh radj oll y barvensa 107 Reflektys dhe'n summ a'gan mobyl kynsa, 108 Owth kemer ena byw ha postrans.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 E come clivo in acqua di suo imo 110 si specchia, quasi per vedersi addorno, 111 quando è nel verde e ne’ fioretti opimo,
112 sì, soprastando al lume intorno intorno, 113 vidi specchiarsi in più di mille soglie 114 quanto di noi là sù fatto ha ritorno.
query.result:
**English:**
109 And as a cliff in water at its foot 110 mirrors itself, as if to see itself adorned, 111 when it is lush with greenery and flowers,
112 so, rising above the light all around, 113 I saw mirrored in more than a thousand thresholds 114 all that of us has returned up there.
**Cornish:**
109 Ha kevel avel yn dowr y’y isledh 110 a wra dhe weles orth y honan, 111 pan yw gwyrdh ha bleujyow yn foen,
112 keffrys, ow tos dhe golow tro-dro, 113 yth welyv dhe wra dhe weles yn moy ages mil 114 an oll a ni a wrug returnya.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 E se l’infimo grado in sé raccoglie 116 sì grande lume, quanta è la larghezza 117 di questa rosa ne l’estreme foglie!
118 La vista mia ne l’ampio e ne l’altezza 119 non si smarriva, ma tutto prendeva 120 il quanto e ’l quale di quella allegrezza.
query.result:
**English:**
115 And if the lowest level gathers in itself 116 such great light, how vast is the expanse 117 of this rose in its outermost petals!
118 My sight was not lost in the breadth and height, 119 but took in all the quantity and quality 120 of that joy.
**Cornish:**
115 Ha gen an renk isa yn keverel 116 golow mawr avel hyn, pyth yw an lewder 117 a’n rosma ma yn y delyow esa?
118 Va gweles na veu kollet yn an lewder ha’n ughelder, 119 mes kemerys oll an moyter ha’n kaletter 120 a’n lowena hyn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 Presso e lontano, lì, né pon né leva: 122 ché dove Dio sanza mezzo governa, 123 la legge natural nulla rileva.
query.result:
**English:**
121 Near and far, there, neither bridge nor lever: 122 for where God governs without intermediary, 123 natural law is of no account.
**Cornish:**
121 Kres ha pell, eno, nag lever nag pons: 122 rag le may Duw heb kres govern, 123 an lagha naturel nyns yw gwerth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Nel giallo de la rosa sempiterna, 125 che si digrada e dilata e redole 126 odor di lode al sol che sempre verna,
127 qual è colui che tace e dicer vole, 128 mi trasse Bëatrice, e disse: «Mira 129 quanto è ’l convento de le bianche stole!
130 Vedi nostra città quant’ ella gira; 131 vedi li nostri scanni sì ripieni, 132 che poca gente più ci si disira.
query.result:
**English:**
124 In the yellow of the eternal rose, 125 which fades and expands and exhales 126 an odor of praise to the sun that is always spring,
127 like one who is silent and wants to speak, 128 Beatrice drew me to her and said: "Look 129 how great is the assembly of the white robes!
130 See how vast our city is; 131 see our seats so full, 132 that few more people are desired here.
**Cornish:**
124 Yn melyn an ros sempiterna, 125 hag a wra dhe weles ha dhe leskel ha dhe areli 126 sawor a molleth dhe’n howl a wra bynnas bys vyth,
127 kepar ha neb a wra dhe dhedhes ha karas leverel, 128 Bëatrice a’m gorra ha leverel: “Gwel 129 pyth yw brassa an konvent a’n mantellyow gwynn!
130 Gwel pyth yw brassa niver sita; 131 gwel niverow niver leun avel hyn, 132 bys na wra moy a dusow karys ena.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 E ’n quel gran seggio a che tu li occhi tieni 134 per la corona che già v’è sù posta, 135 prima che tu a queste nozze ceni,
136 sederà l’alma, che fia giù agosta, 137 de l’alto Arrigo, ch’a drizzare Italia 138 verrà in prima ch’ella sia disposta.
query.result:
**English:**
133 And in that great seat to which you keep your eyes fixed 134 because of the crown that is already placed there, 135 before you feast at these nuptials,
136 will sit the soul, who will be revered below, 137 of the noble Henry, who will come to set Italy straight 138 before she is ready.
**Cornish:**
133 Ha yn an sedh mawr ena dhe weles dhodha 134 rag an kurun a wra ena settys, 135 kyns termyn bos te dhe’n nosva hyn,
136 y fia’n eneval, hag a wra jynnys isella, 137 a’n Arrigo uhel, hag a dheuth dhe wosa Itali 138 kyns bos parys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
139 La cieca cupidigia che v’ammalia 140 simili fatti v’ha al fantolino 141 che muor per fame e caccia via la balia.
query.result:
**English:**
139 The blind greed that bewitches you 140 makes you act like the baby 141 who dies of hunger and pushes away the wet nurse.
**Cornish:**
139 An fella brys a wra dhe ammali 140 a wra dhe wul orth dhe wosa kepar 141 an baban byghan a wra dhe verwel drefen ha dhe gwaya an balia.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
142 E fia prefetto nel foro divino 143 allora tal, che palese e coverto 144 non anderà con lui per un cammino.
query.result:
**English:**
142 And such a one will be prefect in the divine court 143 then, that openly and secretly 144 he will not walk with him on the same path.
**Cornish:**
142 Ha prefett y fia yn an lys divin 143 ena an prys, leun a wra dhe weles ha dhe gudhes 144 na wra dhe kerdhes gans an prys hyn war an fordh an keth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
145 Ma poco poi sarà da Dio sofferto 146 nel santo officio; ch’el sarà detruso 147 là dove Simon mago è per suo merto,
148 e farà quel d’Alagna intrar più giuso».
query.result:
**English:**
145 But he will soon be removed from his holy office by God; 146 for he will be cast down 147 to where Simon Magus is for his deserts,
148 and he will make the one from Anagni enter even lower.
**Cornish:**
145 Mes byghan wosa y fia sufferys gans Duw 146 yn an offis sans; rag y fia treghys 147 ena le may Simon Magus yw rag y werth,
148 ha y fia gul an neb a Alagna dhe vos isella.
